The IEEE Trial-Use Standard for Testability and Diagnosability Characteristics and Metrics is not part of the introduction.
The objective of the testability initiative is to make systems easier to test.

The IEEE 1232TM Artificial Intelligence Exchange and Service Tie to All Test Environments series of standards provide the foundation for precise and unambiguous testability and diagnosability metrics.
The objective of this standard is to provide notionally correct and inherently useful but mathematically precise definitions of testability measures.

IEEE developed the standard for testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics.
The standard was developed by the Diagnostic and Maintenance Control subcommittee.
The standard was developed for the IEEE Standards Coordinating Committee 20.
The standard provides standard definitions of testability and diagnosability metrics and characteristics.
The standard builds on fundamental definitions derived from IEEE Std 1232TM-2002.
The goals of the standard are to provide standard definitions.
Provide definitions of testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics that are independent of specific test and diagnosis technologies.
Provide definitions of testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics that are independent of specific system under test technologies.
Provide unambiguous definitions of testability and diagnosability metrics used by procurement and support organizations.
Lord Kelvin commented that when you can measure what you are speaking about and express it in numbers, you know something about it.
Lord Kelvin commented that when you cannot measure it, you cannot express it.
Lord Kelvin commented that when you can measure what you are speaking about and express it in numbers, your knowledge is of a meager and unsatisfactory kind.
Lord Kelvin commented that when you cannot measure it, your knowledge is of a meager and unsatisfactory kind.
Lord Kelvin commented that when you can measure what you are speaking about and express it in numbers, you know something about it; and when you cannot measure it, you cannot express it
Lord Kelvin’s insight is that when different tools measure something differently, and the basis for the measurement is not known or understood, it is neither knowledge nor science.
The objective of this standard is to provide precise formal definitions of metrics that may be used to predict the testability of a system.
Predictive metrics may be used iteratively during various phases of design and diagnostic development to map the progress toward a project’s testability goals.
Empirical metrics are derived from actual maintenance data to determine the testability achieved during the factory and field testing of a system.
Information for references can be found in Clause 2.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a trial-use standard for testability and diagnosability.
Predictive testability and diagnosability metrics are defined based on IEEE Std 1232-2002.
Entities required that have not been defined in these information models are provided by this standard in the form of an AI-ESTATE extension.
This standard does not impose any implementation-specific requirements for actually computing the metrics.
Metrics not computed using the identified standard information models must be demonstrated to be mathematically equivalent to the definitions provided.
This standard defines technology-independent testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics.
This standard defines testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics based on relevant standard information models, including standard AI-ESTATE information models.
This standard assumes that no more than a single independent fault exists at the time of diagnostics.
Multiple fault metrics are outside the scope of this standard because of a lack of industry consensus as to how those metrics should be calculated.
This standard provides consistent definitions of testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics.
A common basis for system testability and diagnosability assessment will be provided.
Specifications in the EXPRESS language are given in the Courier type font.
The standard uses the vocabulary and definitions of relevant IEEE standards.
Specifications in the EXPRESS language include references to entity and attribute names in the supporting text.
IEEE Std 1232-2002 takes precedence in case of conflict of definitions.
Portions of IEEE Std 1232-2002 are repeated in this standard for clarity.
This standard shall be used in conjunction with IEEE Std 1232-2002.
The current, approved version of IEEE Std 1232-2002 takes precedence in case of revision to AI-ESTATE.

ISO publications are available from the ISO Central Secretariat.

The Authoritative Dictionary of IEEE Standards and Terms, Seventh edition should be referenced for terms not defined in this clause.
The standard describes its behavior under test.
The behavior under test may or may not be measurable during actual system operation or maintenance.
Faults in a system can be localized.
Fault localization can be done frequently and unambiguously.
Fault localization can be done efficiently.
Faults are measured during system operation and maintenance.
Fault isolation is to be performed efficiently.
Systems became more complex, costly, and difficult to diagnose and repair.
Initiatives were started to address these problems.
Test points are needed in the right places.
System design has to include characteristics to make the system easier to test.
Testability is considered as a design characteristic.
Testability is a design characteristic which allows the status of an item to be determined.
Fault isolation within an item can be performed in a timely manner.
MIL-STD-2165 provides uniform procedures and methods to control planning, implementation, and verification of testability.
MIL-STD-2165 provides useful guidance to government suppliers.
Commercial system developers have used MIL-STD-2165 to guide their activities.
Testability is made up of two related practices.
Design for test facilitates the testing process by encouraging good design practices.
Diagnosability is evaluated within the discipline of testability.
Formal, unambiguous definitions of testability and diagnosability metrics and characteristics have been unavailable.
This standard defines metrics related to fault detection and isolation.
Fault detection metrics are represented as a ratio of detected or detectable faults to the full set of possible faults.
The ratio is weighted using the failure rates of the faults within the fault universe.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a trial-use standard.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is for testability and diagnosability.
Fault isolation metrics are based on a ratio of faults in ambiguity groups.
Fault isolation calculations are frequently weighted using failure rates.
Testability has been concerned with fault detection and fault isolation.
Testability has been concerned with false indication issues.
No consensus exists in the test industry for predicting false indication.
This standard will defer specification of metrics for false indication.
False indication issues are complex.
No consensus exists in the test industry for predicting false indication.
This standard distinguishes between predictive and empirical metrics.
Predictive metrics include testability and diagnosability metrics.
Empirical metrics are derived from collected maintenance data.
Clause 5 provides several fundamental measures for testability and diagnosability.
Fundamental measures are defined using the AI-ESTATE information models.
Clause 6 uses fundamental measures to define standard metrics.
Predictive metrics are derived from a static AI-ESTATE-compliant model.
Empirical metrics are beyond the scope of this standard.
Clause 5 provides several fundamental measures for testability and diagnosability.
Fundamental measures are defined using the AI-ESTATE information models.
Clause 6 uses fundamental measures to define standard metrics.
The standard defines the architecture of an AI-ESTATE-conformant system.
The standard defines the information models for knowledge and data exchange.
The standard defines a set of standard software services.

The purpose of this standard is to provide semantically rigorous definitions.

The standard is for test and diagnosis.
AI-ESTATE provides formal definitions of information required for test and diagnosis.
AI-ESTATE is used as the basis for metrics defined within this standard.
Clause 6 describes how to use fundamentals to develop metrics.
Conformance demands that all metrics be computed as specified in Clause 6.
The AI-ESTATE standard defines testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics.
The standard testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics are defined in this standard.
Metrics are computed as specified in Clause 6 for conformance.
The standard provides an extensibility mechanism for future enhancement.
Failure rate is accounted for by extending the AI-ESTATE models with the EXTEND schema.
The EXTEND schema is used to extend the AI-ESTATE models.
Extensions are nonconformant but an extensibility mechanism is provided.
Extensions should be submitted to the D&MC Subcommittee for consideration.
Proposed extensions are ranked in order of preference.
Metrics are derived strictly from the fundamental measures of Clause 5.
Metrics are derived from functions and measures based on the AI-ESTATE models.
Metrics are derived from functions and measures based on the AI-ESTATE models in combination with AI-ESTATE-conformant extensions.
The fundamental measures are categorized as either aggregation measures, cost-related measures, or measures to support detection and isolation metrics.
The specific measures are listed in Table 1.
The approach to defining standard, unambiguous testability and diagnosability metrics is based on the assumption that standard information models provide formal semantics for information of interest.
Standard information models provide formal semantics for information of interest to the testability and diagnosability domain.
The fundamental measures are defined using terminology from EXPRESS models defined in AI-ESTATE.
The approach to specifying measures follows the conventions for defining services in AI-ESTATE.
The primary information models used to define these measures are drawn from the AI-ESTATE standard.
The AI-ESTATE common element model and fault tree models are used to define these measures.
The specific models used include the AI-ESTATE common element model and fault tree models.
The fundamental measures are based on the following propositions.
The fundamental measures are defined using terminology from EXPRESS models defined in AI-ESTATE.
The approach to specifying measures follows the conventions for defining services in AI-ESTATE.
The primary information models used to define these measures are drawn from the AI-ESTATE standard.
The AI-ESTATE common element model and fault tree models are used to define these measures.
The specific models used include the AI-ESTATE common element model and fault tree models.
The fundamental measures are based on the following propositions.
The propositions include the AI-ESTATE common element model and fault tree models.
The propositions are used to define the fundamental measures.
All cost-related metrics are computed with respect to a single test or repair.
Metrics are computed with respect to a single test or repair within the AI-ESTATE common element model.
Isolation metrics are computed under the assumption that no more than a single, independent fault exists at the time of diagnostics.
Isolation metrics are computed without dependence on diagnostic and maintenance strategies.
The type of underlying diagnostic model will establish detectability and isolatability differently.
The AI-ESTATE model defines the level entity to be the level of indenture for a particular hierarchical element.
The type of underlying diagnostic model will establish detectability and isolatability differently.
The AI-ESTATE model defines the level entity to be the level of indenture for a particular hierarchical element.
Many measures are defined relative to a level defined within the AI-ESTATE model.
The level entity is defined within the AI-ESTATE model.

IEEE Std 1522-2004 defines the total repair non-time cost.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 defines the total repair time cost.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 defines the total test non-time cost.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 defines the total test time cost.
IEEE provides the definition of each aggregation fundamental to be used in more complex metric definitions.
All fundamental measures are based on the AI-ESTATE common element model.
Actions are the primary entities against which costs are associated.
The diagnosis and repair process is concerned with optimizing the sequence of actions required to return a unit to service.
The function action_set returns the set of all actions within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A diagnosis is defined by the information model to be a lattice of diagnostic conclusions.
A diagnosis consists of failures or faults.
The diagnoses can be interconnected in a lattice to classify constituent units by function.
The function diagnosis_set returns the set of all diagnoses within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A failure mode is defined by the information model to be a specific mode or means by which a unit or system can fail.
A failure mode is associated with the diagnosis and then with the item that has failed.
The function failure_mode_set returns the set of all failure modes within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
Failure modes are associated with diagnoses within the model.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a trial-use standard for testability.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a copyright of 2005 IEEE.
All rights are reserved by IEEE.
A failure is defined as a manifestation of an anomaly within a system.
A failure is defined as the failure of the system under test to perform some intended function.
The function failure_set returns the set of all failures within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A fault is defined as a physical cause of anomalous behavior within a system.
A fault typically corresponds to some physical breakdown in the system under test.
The function fault_set returns the set of all faults within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A function is defined as any functional behavior represented within a system.
The function entity is intended to provide a placeholder for functional information in the event the diagnostic or testability model is function-oriented.
The function function_set returns the set of all functions within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A repair item is defined as some part of the system to be adjusted, calibrated, repaired, replaced, etc.
A diagnosis shall lead the maintainer to the object of the maintenance action.
The function repair_item_set returns the set of all repair items within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A repair is defined as the process undertaken to return the unit to service.
The function repair_set returns the set of all repairs within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A resource is defined as something that any given action in the maintenance process is likely to require to perform that action.
resource_set returns the set of all resources within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
resource_set is a function.
resource_set takes two parameters: mdl and lvl.
mdl is a diagnostic model.
lvl is a level.
resource_set returns a set of resources.
The subclause provides the definition of each cost-related fundamental.
All fundamental measures are based on the AI-ESTATE common element model.
cost-related measures are defined in this standard.
This standard applies the categories of cost types as specified in AI-ESTATE.
The categories of cost types are time cost and non-time cost.
Cost is computed over a set of tests or repairs.
Cost calculations use associated test action costs, repair action costs, and resource costs.
All cost calculations use the same units of measure.
Cost calculations are based on resource cost.
No unit conversion is included in the definition.
measures are specified in four versions.
Each version is associated with a particular level and a particular required context.
Each version is associated with a particular level but all contexts.
Each version is associated with a particular required context but all levels.
Each version is associated with no level and no required context specified.
The context refers to the required set of conditions.
The context is specified within AI-ESTATE.
The context is required when specified test, diagnosis, or repair is performed.
A model structure is provided to capture failure rate information.
The model structure is provided within AI-ESTATE.
The failure rate is defined based on clock time or operating time.
Clock time includes the time when the system is not in operation.
Operating time does not include the time when the system is not in operation.
The time basis attribute permits specification of a user-defined basis.
The time basis attribute permits specification that the basis is unknown.
IEEE 1232-2002 lacks an attribute.
An extension to AI-ESTATE has been specified in Annex C.
The function probability_of_diagnosis returns the conditional probability of a diagnosis given a specified set of diagnoses.
The probability is calculated as the failure rate of the specified diagnosis, divided by the sum of the failure rates of the diagnoses in the specified set.
The underlying distribution would be used to derive a probability at a specified point in time for the members of the set.
The probability of diagnosis would be computed by normalizing over the specified set.
The probability of diagnosis is computed relative to a specified set of diagnoses.
The diagnosis for which the probability is being calculated is a member of the specified diagnosis set.
No diagnosis in the relative diagnosis set is a child of another diagnosis in the specified diagnosis set.
The time basis is consistent for all members of the diagnosis set.
The set of diagnoses does not mix faults and failures.
The diagnoses in the specified set are probabilistically independent of one another.
The probability is then calculated using the extended diagnosis entity defined in Annex C.
The measure probability_of_repair_item_set represents the probability that a set of repair items is diagnosed.
The probability of a repair item is defined as the sum of the probabilities of diagnosis for all diagnoses tied to that repair item.
No diagnosis in the repair item is a child of another diagnosis in the same repair item.
The time basis is consistent for all diagnoses in the repair item.
The set of diagnoses in the repair item does not mix faults and failures.
Computing the probability of a diagnosis uses the probability_of_diagnosis function defined here.
The diagnoses in the specified set are probabilistically independent of one another.

Diagnostic models defined in AI-ESTATE common element model.
Diagnostic models include FTM, DIM, or EDIM.
Diagnostic models include an instance of the diagnosis entity corresponding to No Fault.
Diagnoses that are detectable or isolatable by the set of tests included in the model are identified.
Diagnostic models used to specify measures include an instance of the diagnosis entity corresponding to No Fault.
The ability to define metrics based on detection and isolation within a diagnostic model is fundamental.
All diagnoses that are detectable or isolatable by the set of tests included in the model are identified.
Metrics are to be computed based on a predefined universe of diagnoses and a predefined set of tests.
Actual measures of isolation depend on the algorithms used to perform diagnosis.

The standard became impractical to delineate all possible metrics.
Metrics can be tailored to answer specific questions about the testability of a system.
The standard does not exclude worthwhile metrics.
The metrics in this clause all use fundamentals.
Several metrics are included as informative, rather than as normative.
The informative metrics illustrate the process of developing a metric.
Metrics developed using the fundamentals can be submitted to the D&MC Subcommittee.
The subclause provides definitions of the testability and diagnosability metrics.
The metrics quantify the fault detection capability of a given diagnostic model.
There are two detection metrics in this standard.
One metric describes a diagnostic model’s fault detection capability as an unweighted percentage.
The standard provides definitions of the testability and diagnosability metrics.
The metrics quantify the fault detection capability of a given diagnostic model.
There are two detection metrics in this standard.
One metric describes a diagnostic model’s fault detection capability as an unweighted percentage.
The other metric uses a percentage weighted by probability of diagnosis.

The standard defines a metric called Percentage of detection.
The metric is described by Equation (1).
The metric calculates the percentage of possible diagnoses at a particular level.
The metric uses a specified diagnostic model and a given set of tests.
EPoD is a failure probability-weighted percentage of possible diagnoses.
EPoD is calculated within a specified diagnostic model.
EPoD is calculated at a particular level within a model.
EPoD is calculated using a given set of tests.

EPoD is calculated for a diagnostic model.
EPoD is calculated at a specified level of a model.
EPoD is calculated using tests defined within a model.
This subclause provides definitions of testability and diagnosability metrics.
There are six fault isolation metrics.
The metrics quantify the fault isolation capability of a diagnostic model.
Each fault isolation metric is described by an equation.
The metrics include percentage of isolation, expected percentage of isolation, and others.
The metrics are used to quantify the fault isolation capability of a model.
The metrics are described by equations.
The metrics are used to evaluate a diagnostic model.
The first and sixth metrics are unweighted.
The other four metrics are weighted using probability of diagnosis.
The metrics include expected percentage of isolation, expected ambiguity group size, and others.
The metrics are used to quantify the fault isolation capability of a model.
The metrics are described by equations.
The metrics are used to evaluate a diagnostic model.
The metrics include isolation effectiveness and projected effect of ambiguity upon false removals.
The metrics are used to evaluate a diagnostic model.
Percentage of isolation consists of two individual equations.
The incremental percentage of isolation is the percentage of all diagnosis ambiguity groups that can be isolated.
The incremental percentage of isolation is described by Equation (3).
The cumulative percentage of isolation is the percentage of all diagnosis ambiguity groups that can be isolated.
The cumulative percentage of isolation is described by Equation (4).
The incremental percentage of isolation is calculated for a particular level of a model.
The cumulative percentage of isolation is calculated for a particular level of a model.
The metrics are used to quantify the fault isolation capability of a model.
Cumulative percentage of isolation is the percentage of all diagnosis ambiguity groups that can be isolated.
Cumulative percentage of isolation is described by Equation (4).
Cumulative percentage of isolation is calculated for a particular level of a model.
Cumulative percentage of isolation is calculated using tests defined within a model.
Cumulative percentage of isolation is calculated for a diagnostic model.
Cumulative percentage of isolation is calculated at a specified level of a model.
Cumulative percentage of isolation is calculated using a specified number of repair items.
Cumulative percentage of isolation is calculated using the maximum size of an ambiguity group.
n is the specified number of repair items

Isolation effectiveness (IE) is a measure of how well the repair item ambiguity groups that can be isolated using tests defined within that model conform to a specified diagnostic goal.

IE is, for a particular level of a given diagnostic model, a measure of how well the repair item ambiguity groups that can be isolated using tests defined within that model conform to a specified diagnostic goal.

Repair item involvement ratio (RIIR) is, for a particular level of a given diagnostic model, the number of repair item ambiguity groups that contain a given repair item divided by the total number of ambiguity groups at that level that can be isolated using tests defined within that model.
RIIR is described by Equation (11).

Fault detection and isolation metrics can be calculated over an entire design.
Fault detection and isolation metrics can be calculated over an explicitly defined functional subset of that design.
The following list provides some typical types of subsets that may be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
Functionality can be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
Technology can be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
Operational usage can be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
Hardware source can be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
Operating mode can be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
Test domain can be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
Fault universe can be used to constrain the fault detection metrics for a design.
The equations defined in this clause can be used to calculate the metrics for a particular functional subset of a design.
The model must be constructed such that only the desired subset is represented.
PEFR mdl lvl can be used to calculate the metrics for a particular functional subset of a design.
IEisol mdl lvl can be used to calculate the metrics for a particular functional subset of a design.
Fault detection and isolation metrics are frequently constrained by test class.
Fault detection and isolation metrics are frequently constrained to calculate the fault coverage associated with different subsets of tests within the design.
BIT type can be used to constrain analysis.
Diagnostic usage can be used to constrain analysis.
Test implementations can be used to constrain analysis.
The equations defined in this clause can be used to calculate the metrics for a particular subset of tests within a design.
The model must be constructed such that only the desired subset is represented.
The diagnosis failure probabilities used to calculate the EPoD and EPoI are generally derived from failure rates.
The diagnosis failure probabilities used to calculate the EPoD and EPoI are generally derived from failure rates.
Failure rates describe expected rates of failure.
Failure rates are usually expressed in terms of failures per million hours.
The same metric equation can be used to calculate EPoD and EPoI over a specific time interval.
EPoD and EPoI can be calculated over a specific time interval.
The specified diagnostic model represents the number of failures.
The specified diagnostic model represents the number of failures over an arbitrarily long time interval.
The specified diagnostic model represents the number of failures over the first two years of deployment.
failures are expected within a given time interval.
failures are expected rather than the number of failures per million hours.

The product life cycle process is related to diagnostic analysis and design.
A comprehensive diagnostic analysis and design program requires a dedicated effort.
The diagnostic design life cycle is organized around five phases.
The five phases are: Requirements definition, Architecture design, Detailed test design, Verification and validation, and Diagnostic maturation.
Each phase is described in a separate section.
Requirements definition is the first step in an effective testability program.
Diagnostic requirements are typically expressed in performance terms.
Diagnostic requirements express the desired outcome without directing how to achieve it.
Requirements definition is the first step in an effective testability program.
Diagnostic requirements are typically expressed in performance terms.
Diagnostic requirements express the desired outcome without directing how to achieve it.
Goals are typically specified for fault detection, fault isolation, and fault isolation resolution.
Mission reliability is a related requirement examined early in the design phase.
Mission reliability is a measure of the prognostic capability of a system.
Mission reliability is shown analytically to be capable of predicting system operation without malfunction.
Other system-level metrics may be specified at this time.
Mission reliability is a related requirement examined early in the design phase.
Mission reliability is a measure of the prognostic capability of a system.
Mission reliability is shown analytically to be capable of predicting system operation without malfunction.
Mean time between failure (MTBF) is a system-level metric.
Operational availability is a system-level metric.
Can not duplicate (CND)/no evidence of failure (NEOF) rate is a system-level metric.
Mean time between unscheduled maintenance actions (MTBUMA) is a system-level metric.
Derivative requirements include mean time to repair (MTTR) and maintenance frequency.
Derivative requirements include mean time to repair (MTTR) and maintenance frequency.
Derivative requirements also include skill levels of repair personnel and time required for maintenance.
Customer warranties may be executed on some metrics such as MTBF or operational availability.
Customer warranties may also be executed on total operating hours.
Authorized licensed use is limited to Technische Universitat Kaiserslautern.

The document is copyrighted by IEEE in 2005.
The intent in the architecture design phase is to develop a preliminary design framework.
The design framework allocates diagnostic program requirements to physical system components.
A basic diagnostic subsystem architecture is laid out in conjunction with trade studies.
Trade studies include fault tolerance, fault reporting, and field update approaches.
The evaluation of the system's fault tolerance is against cost, weight, power, and MTBF.
Alternative architectures are evaluated against cost, weight, power, and MTBF.
The evaluation of the system's fault tolerance is important for architecture design.
The evaluation of the system's fault tolerance is a key consideration in architecture design.
Subsystem requirements are allocated to individual hardware elements.
System-level testability models may be created to support analysis.
Testability analysis is performed on the design models to verify requirements.
Functional/physical partitioning and diagnostic requirements allocation will satisfy top-level requirements.
Testability analysis is performed in a top-down manner.
Testability models should evolve with the design.
Testability analysis is performed to verify diagnostic requirements allocation.
Detailed design requirements are allocated to individual hardware elements.
Diagnostic design influence is assured by identifying necessary diagnostic design features.
An elementary framework for a test strategy begins to emerge during analysis.
Diagnostic program requirements are met by developing a detailed design solution.
Detailed hardware and software designs are created in accordance with allocated system requirements.
Diagnostic and reliability trade studies are iterated as required.
Allocations of FD, FI, and FIR are adjusted as necessary.
The results of modifications are reflected in the models and verified.
Diagnostic and reliability trade studies affect cost, weight, power, MTBCF, and MTBF.
The physical design matures as hardware aspects are reflected in analysis models.
The hardware aspects are linked to their functional elements.
The basic diagnostic subsystem architecture is modified as design and support system details emerge.
Diagnostic and reliability trade studies are performed to optimize design.
Fault tolerance, fault reporting, prognostics, and field update approaches are considered.
The results of modifications are reflected in the models and verified.
Diagnostic and reliability trade studies affect cost, weight, power, MTBCF, and MTBF.
The diagnostic subsystem architecture is modified as design details emerge.
Preliminary test verticality is performed during this phase.
Comparative margins and tolerances of tests are determined.
Test consistency is compared between BIT and ATE.
Test consistency is compared between factory and field tests.
Worst-case tolerance variations are considered.
Latent manufacturing defects are considered.
The cone of tolerance analysis is performed.
The results of the analysis are used to determine comparative margins and tolerances.
Diagnostic requirements are validated through test and demonstration.
Diagnostic support equipment is tested or demonstrated.
Diagnostic support system contributions to diagnostics are tested or demonstrated.
Quantitative testability allocations are verified through analysis and inspection methods.
Authorized licensed use limited to: Technische Universitat Kaiserslautern.
Diagnostic requirements are verified on delivery.
Diagnostic support equipment and support system contributions are tested or demonstrated.
Diagnostic requirements are verified through test and demonstration.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a trial-use standard for testability.
Copyright 2005 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Two primary validation efforts are performed during this phase.
The validity of the fault detection and fault isolation models are assessed through a static fault insertion.
Susceptibility to false alarms and can not duplicates is evaluated during field testing opportunities.
Fault insertion is the only controlled opportunity for exercising the complete embedded hardware/software.
Diagnostic software only performs its intended job in the presence of failures.
Faults selected for insertion should be chosen based on highest failure probability.
Diagnostic software must be executed to verify that the tests assumed during the analysis phases were effectively implemented in software.
Faults selected for insertion should be chosen based on highest failure probability.
Corrective actions for FD/FI deficiencies are to be implemented and validated.
False alarms and can not duplicates are undesirable design characteristics.
Development and qualification tests exercise the hardware under simulated environmental and life conditions.
Laboratory and field tests provide an opportunity to correct diagnostic anomalies.
The purpose of the maturation phase is to implement a program that effectively measures actual product performance.
A maturation plan must be constructed to document how data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected.
False alarms and can not duplicates are undesirable design characteristics.
Development and qualification tests exercise the hardware under simulated environmental and life conditions.
Laboratory and field tests provide an opportunity to correct diagnostic anomalies.
The purpose of the maturation phase is to implement a program that effectively measures actual product performance.
A maturation plan must be constructed to document how data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected.
The effort to mature a design begins at the conceptual design stage and continues throughout the system life cycle.
Data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected, measured, evaluated, and acted on.
The state of the diagnostic design will be demonstrated to meet the diagnostic and health management requirements.
The purpose of the maturation phase is to implement a program that effectively measures actual product performance.
A maturation plan must be constructed to document how data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected.
Data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected, measured, evaluated, and acted on.
The state of the diagnostic design will be demonstrated to meet the diagnostic and health management requirements.
Unexpected and unplanned system-level design interactions can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Operational and environmental stresses can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Other influences can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
The performance of the diagnostic design can degrade from what was predicted.
The purpose of the maturation phase is to implement a program that effectively measures actual product performance.
A maturation plan must be constructed to document how data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected.
Data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected, measured, evaluated, and acted on.
The state of the diagnostic design will be demonstrated to meet the diagnostic and health management requirements.
Unexpected and unplanned system-level design interactions can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Operational and environmental stresses can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Other influences can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
The performance of the diagnostic design can degrade from what was predicted.
Remedial actions must be taken for unacceptable product performance or other cost of ownership problems.
Root cause analysis must be performed to identify potential adjustments.
Potential adjustments include improvements or refinements to diagnostic, support, or operational elements.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 defines the specification for extensions of the AI-ESTATE information models.
The AI-ESTATE standard is extended to include the probability_of_diagnosis and probability_of_repair_item_set measures.
The AI-ESTATE common element model is extended to include a failure rate value for each diagnosis.
The failure rate extension is an abstract entity that contains the frequency value for the associated failure rate.
The failure rate extension is a subtype of the failure_rate entity in the AI-ESTATE common element model.
The associated_frequency attribute is used to specify the rate of failures associated with a diagnosis over a given time span.
The EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate entity is a subtype of the abstract entity EXTEND_failure_rate.
beta is a REAL.
beta is an attribute.
alpha is an attribute.
alpha is used to specify the alpha parameter of the Weibull distribution.
beta is used to specify the beta parameter of the Weibull distribution.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is a subtype of EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of an exponential distribution.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is a subtype of EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of an exponential distribution.
EXTEND_diagnosis is a subtype of diagnosis.
EXTEND_diagnosis contains the failure rate for the associated diagnosis.
new_rate is an attribute.
new_rate is used to specify the failure rate associated with the given diagnosis.
